articles.headline: Memo to the Uneasy Investor: Be Strong
articles.snippet: Now is the time for taking deep breaths and chanting mantras, but it’s not a time to get out of the stock market.
articles.abstract: Now is the time for taking deep breaths and chanting mantras, but it’s not a time to get out of the stock market.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s pretty hard to stick with a long-term plan for your money when the financial world seems to be unraveling around you.

articles.headline: Defibrillators Are Lifesaver, but Risks Give Pause
articles.snippet: More doctors and patients are deciding the risks and uncertainties of defibrillators may outweigh their potential benefits.
articles.abstract: More doctors and patients are deciding the risks and uncertainties of defibrillators may outweigh their potential benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: The implanted defibrillator, a device that can automatically shock an erratically beating heart back to a normal rhythm, has been proved to save lives. Hence its nickname: an emergency room in the chest. Major medical groups have recommended that more patients receive the devices.

articles.headline: U.S. Holds the Whip Hand in Modifying Mortgages
articles.snippet: Regulators are walking a fine line between protecting the government from losses and helping struggling homeowners and the broader economy, according to financial and political analysts.
articles.abstract: Regulators are walking a fine line between protecting the government from losses and helping struggling homeowners and the broader economy, according to financial and political analysts.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of the last year, Washington officials have been pressing the mortgage industry to modify home loans and avoid foreclosures. Now, the extraordinary government intervention in Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and a growing number of banks puts federal agencies in the powerful, and awkward, position of deciding which borrowers will receive help and who will lose their home.

articles.headline: Stuck in Google’s Doghouse
articles.snippet: Some say that Google’s near monopoly in search ads puts it in a position to decide which business models it will tolerate and which ones it won’t.
articles.abstract: Some say that Google’s near monopoly in search ads puts it in a position to decide which business models it will tolerate and which ones it won’t.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few days ago, Dan Savage had his lawyer send a nine-page, 4,000-word letter to the antitrust division of the Justice Department. Mr. Savage, 59, runs Sourcetool.com, a business-to-business Web site that acts as a directory, listing  and ranking  hundreds of thousands of companies that sell industrial products.

articles.headline: In Tangle of Young Lips, a Sex Rebellion in Chile
articles.snippet: In a country of very traditional social mores, youths are living in an unprecedented period of sexual exploration.
articles.abstract: In a country of very traditional social mores, youths are living in an unprecedented period of sexual exploration.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile  It is just after 5 p.m. in what was once one of Latin America’s most sexually conservative countries, and the youth of Chile are bumping and grinding to a reggaetón beat. At the Bar Urbano disco, boys and girls ages 14 to 18 are stripping off their shirts, revealing bras, tattoos and nipple rings.

articles.headline: Lehman and Its Staff Await Next Step
articles.snippet: As rank-and-file employees confronted an uncertain future, top executives huddled in all-day meetings and braced for takeover bids, expected by Saturday afternoon.
articles.abstract: As rank-and-file employees confronted an uncertain future, top executives huddled in all-day meetings and braced for takeover bids, expected by Saturday afternoon.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was no ordinary Friday at Lehman Brothers. “You Shook Me All Night Long” by AC/DC blared from speakers inside the bank’s Midtown headquarters. Employees polished résumés. And, by midafternoon, the word came from the 31st floor: the fate of the stricken bank would be decided by Sunday.
articles.byline: By Ben White and Eric Dash

articles.headline: U.S. Gives Banks Urgent Warning to Solve Crisis
articles.snippet: Three top officials convened the heads of Wall Street’s biggest investment banks for an emergency meeting to impress upon them the need to find a plan to rescue Lehman Brothers.
articles.abstract: Three top officials convened the heads of Wall Street’s biggest investment banks for an emergency meeting to impress upon them the need to find a plan to rescue Lehman Brothers.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Jenny Anderson, Edmund L. Andrews, Vikas Bajaj and Eric Dash and written by Mr. Dash.

articles.headline: Sweet Dreams in Hard Times Add to Lottery Sales
articles.snippet: Many state lotteries are experiencing record sales, as some try to turn a lottery ticket into a ticket back to prosperity.
articles.abstract: Many state lotteries are experiencing record sales, as some try to turn a lottery ticket into a ticket back to prosperity.
articles.lead_paragraph: When gasoline prices shot up this year, Peggy Seemann thought about saving the $10 she spends weekly on lottery tickets.

articles.headline: McCain Barbs Stirring Outcry as Distortions
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain has drawn criticism for stretching the truth in attacking Senator Barack Obama’s positions.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain has drawn criticism for stretching the truth in attacking Senator Barack Obama’s positions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Harsh advertisements and negative attacks are a staple of presidential campaigns, but Senator John McCain has drawn an avalanche of criticism this week from Democrats, independent groups and even some Republicans for regularly stretching the truth in attacking Senator Barack Obama’s record and positions.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Florida Deal for Everglades May Help Big Sugar
articles.snippet: Florida’s plan to buy one of the state’s two large sugar enterprises may be a boon to the remaining sugar giant.
articles.abstract: Florida’s plan to buy one of the state’s two large sugar enterprises may be a boon to the remaining sugar giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN June, Gov. Charlie Crist announced that Florida would buy one of the state’s two big sugar enterprises, the United States Sugar Corporation. He billed the purchase as a “jump-start” in the environmental restoration of the Everglades, which cane growers are accused of polluting with fertilizer runoff.

articles.headline: Economy to Entrepreneurs: Turn Back
articles.snippet: Amid the current economic turmoil, many entrepreneurs and small-business owners are debating whether it makes sense to seek safety in the corporate life — and deciding that it does.
articles.abstract: Amid the current economic turmoil, many entrepreneurs and small-business owners are debating whether it makes sense to seek safety in the corporate life — and deciding that it does.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN 2000, Bobbi Reed moved from Denver to Sydney, Australia, for a month and ran a V.I.P. hospitality suite at the Summer Olympic Games. Two years later, at the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City, she and her team hosted 1,100 telecommunication workers, handling their food, housing and transportation.

articles.headline: The Joys of Ownership
articles.snippet: Legal fees and exit packages are nothing next to the billions in potential losses we face as taxpayers in having to guarantee bad mortgages that Mac ’n’ Mae financed during the boom.
articles.abstract: Legal fees and exit packages are nothing next to the billions in potential losses we face as taxpayers in having to guarantee bad mortgages that Mac ’n’ Mae financed during the boom.
articles.lead_paragraph: SO, ladies and gentlemen, how does it feel to be the new owner of those two big and banged-up mortgage companies, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac? Not exactly the kind of real estate you were looking to buy, you say? Felt you had swallowed enough garbage after the Bear Stearns bailout tapped you for $29 billion?

articles.headline: Wall St. Goliath Teeters Amid Fear of Wider Crisis
articles.snippet: As Lehman Brothers sought a buyer, officials moved to stop a downward spiral threatening other institutions.
articles.abstract: As Lehman Brothers sought a buyer, officials moved to stop a downward spiral threatening other institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fearing that Lehman Brothers is only days away from collapse, government officials and senior Wall Street executives met on Saturday to try to arrest a downward spiral that might imperil other financial institutions.

articles.headline: Once Elected, Palin Hired Friends and Lashed Foes
articles.snippet: Gov. Sarah Palin’s visceral style and tendency to attack critics contrast with her public image, her record shows.
articles.abstract: Gov. Sarah Palin’s visceral style and tendency to attack critics contrast with her public image, her record shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Jo Becker, Peter S. Goodman and Michael Powell.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker, Peter S. Goodman and Michael Powell

articles.headline: Rail Line Says Train Ran Signal; Death Toll at 25
articles.snippet: The number of dead in the Los Angeles crash may rise, officials said, because 40 people were in critical condition.
articles.abstract: The number of dead in the Los Angeles crash may rise, officials said, because 40 people were in critical condition.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  An engineer who ran a red signal here and crashed head-on into a freight train likely caused the nation’s deadliest commuter train wreck in nearly four decades, a spokeswoman for the rail line said Saturday.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Staying in Galveston, a Park Bench for Shelter
articles.snippet: In Galveston, Tex., which lost 6,000 people in 1900, there is a grim calculation with each storm: stay or go?
articles.abstract: In Galveston, Tex., which lost 6,000 people in 1900, there is a grim calculation with each storm: stay or go?
articles.lead_paragraph: GALVESTON, Tex.  Those who make the barrier island here their home know this: Nature tries to wipe them out now and then. They live with that knowledge every day, though it does not come to the forefront of their thinking unless a storm is on the way.
articles.byline: By Ian Urbina and John Schwartz

articles.headline: Storm Damage Is Extensive and Millions Lose Power
articles.snippet: There were reports of as many as four people killed, but it could take days to search flooded homes to assess the extent of the impact of Hurricane Ike.
articles.abstract: There were reports of as many as four people killed, but it could take days to search flooded homes to assess the extent of the impact of Hurricane Ike.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  Hurricane Ike barreled across a wide swath of Texas on Saturday, deluging the city of Galveston with a wall of water, flooding coastal towns and leaving extensive damage across metropolitan Houston.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and James C. McKinley Jr

articles.headline: Lehman Files for Bankruptcy; Merrill Is Sold
articles.snippet: Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy protection, while Merrill Lynch agreed to sell itself to Bank of America.
articles.abstract: Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy protection, while Merrill Lynch agreed to sell itself to Bank of America.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Jenny Anderson, Eric Dash and Andrew Ross Sorkin and was written by Mr. Sorkin.

articles.headline: Banks Fear Next Move by Shorts
articles.snippet: Some investors are afraid that fund managers will target weak financial firms.
articles.abstract: Some investors are afraid that fund managers will target weak financial firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: In May, David Einhorn, one of the most vocal short-sellers on Wall Street, made no secret he was betting against Lehman Brothers.

articles.headline: A.I.G. Allowed to Borrow Money From Subsidiaries
articles.snippet: New York will allow A.I.G. to borrow $20 billion from its subsidiaries to bolster its capital as it faces huge credit downgrades.
articles.abstract: New York will allow A.I.G. to borrow $20 billion from its subsidiaries to bolster its capital as it faces huge credit downgrades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. David A. Paterson of New York said on Monday that the state would allow the American International Group, a big insurance company, to lend itself $20 billion to bolster its capital as it faces potentially disastrous credit downgrades.
articles.byline: By MICHAEL de la MERCED and GRETCHEN MORGENSON

articles.headline: Nation’s Financial Industry Gripped by Fear
articles.snippet: Fear and greed are the stuff that Wall Street is made of. But inside the great banking houses, those high temples of capitalism, fear came to the fore over the weekend.
articles.abstract: Fear and greed are the stuff that Wall Street is made of. But inside the great banking houses, those high temples of capitalism, fear came to the fore over the weekend.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fear and greed are the stuff that Wall Street is made of. But inside the great banking houses, those high temples of capitalism, fear came to the fore this weekend.
articles.byline: By Ben White and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: After Surviving Storm, Fleeing a Fetid, Devastated Galveston
articles.snippet: For thousands of people stuck on Galveston Island, the aftermath of Hurricane Ike is proving to be worse than the storm.
articles.abstract: For thousands of people stuck on Galveston Island, the aftermath of Hurricane Ike is proving to be worse than the storm.
articles.lead_paragraph: GALVESTON, Tex.  For thousands of people stuck on an increasingly fetid Galveston Island, the aftermath of Hurricane Ike is proving to be far worse than the storm itself.

articles.headline: An Anchor Lets Down Her Hair
articles.snippet: Having a woman in the anchor chair with a history of roaming across all kinds of subject matter might be a pretty good asset.
articles.abstract: Having a woman in the anchor chair with a history of roaming across all kinds of subject matter might be a pretty good asset.
articles.lead_paragraph: The election season has been very good to a woman who seems to be benefiting from her status as an outsider in terms of gender and history. That would be Katie Couric, the anchor of the CBS Evening News.

articles.headline: How a Series of Mistakes Hurt Shares of United
articles.snippet: The plunge in UAL stock was started by a series of human and machine errors and raised questions about the struggles of some traditional media companies to adapt to the Internet age.
articles.abstract: The plunge in UAL stock was started by a series of human and machine errors and raised questions about the struggles of some traditional media companies to adapt to the Internet age.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The swift, sharp and short-lived collapse of United Airlines shares last Monday was followed by a week of finger-pointing.

articles.headline: Obama Raises a Record $66 Million in a Month
articles.snippet: The campaign drew 500,000 first-time donors, crucial new supporters as the senator forgoes public financing.
articles.abstract: The campaign drew 500,000 first-time donors, crucial new supporters as the senator forgoes public financing.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Senator Barack Obama raised more money in August than any presidential candidate has ever recorded in a one-month period, with his campaign disclosing on Sunday that it collected $66 million and drew 500,000 first-time donors to his candidacy.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Michael Luo

articles.headline: Jittery Road Ahead
articles.snippet: Wall Street and the federal government faced off over the weekend, raising worries of a sell-off when markets open on Monday.
articles.abstract: Wall Street and the federal government faced off over the weekend, raising worries of a sell-off when markets open on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street and the federal government played a game of chicken over the weekend, and neither side backed down, pushing Lehman Brothers toward bankruptcy and setting off worries of a worldwide sell-off when markets open on Monday.
articles.byline: By Floyd Norris and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Stunning Fall for Main Street’s Brokerage Firm
articles.snippet: It’s the end of an era for Merrill Lynch, the brokerage firm that brought Wall Street to Main Street.
articles.abstract: It’s the end of an era for Merrill Lynch, the brokerage firm that brought Wall Street to Main Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is the end of an era for Merrill Lynch, the brokerage firm that brought Wall Street to Main Street.
